newsitem.title: UK: London gold price levels off after early dive.
newsitem.headline: London gold price levels off after early dive.

text.p: Gold's strong performance this week turned sour on Friday after heavy selling linked to speculators and mining firms erased recent gains, dealers said.
But prices held steady after an early sharp drop, and analysts said the spent gains had nevertheless strengthened gold's position to stave off falls below recent lows.
Bullion fixed considerably weaker at $379.25 an ounce in the London afternoon and $379.85 in the morning, compared to $383.00 on Thursday afternoon.
In New York's Comex futures market, the price of December gold was down $1.50 an ounce at $380.30.
"What we're seeing is technically driven fund-related selling," a dealer said. "The move up above the $383 area was shown to be a false break out on the charts when gold dipped below $382 yesterday."

Prices had notched up steadily earlier in the week from just under $380 an ounce on Monday to the week's high bid of $384.70. The rise was attributed to cash-rich investment funds deciding that gold would hold above the $377-$379 area.
But gold's failure to hang on above $384 disappointed investors, and trade buyers who had emerged below $379 had turned sellers above $383, helping cap the upside, dealers said.
Some dealers and analysts also noted that substantial volumes of gold may have been sold recently by South African gold miners, due to an attractive rand gold price.
"Gold had a look at the late October peak above $384 this week, but it's been unable to push beyond that," said technical analyst Susan Rigg of Chart Analysis, Ltd.
"I think it may come back down and look at the trough we had in late September and early November."
But support levels at recent lows around $377 an ounce would likely hold again, analysts said.

"The extent of the recent rally has allowed these pictures to improve considerably -- the threatened major breakdown may be averted yet," technical analyst Elli Gifford of Investment Research of Cambridge said in a commentary.
Silver prices eased in sympathy with gold to $4.84/$4.86 an ounce, a loss of five cents from Thursday's London closing. But its movements have been less volatile than gold recently.
Platinum also spiralled back down to $383.75/$384.75 an ounce, down $1.50 after a brisk rally earlier this week which took prices to a a high bid of $389.25 on Thursday.
Palladium was down $2.00 at $117.50/$118.50 an ounce.
